title: Lament Over Jerusalem's Destruction
shortSummary: Psalm 79 is a heartfelt lament by Asaph over the devastation of Jerusalem and the desecration of God's temple by foreign nations. The psalmist pleads for God's mercy, justice, and deliverance, expressing deep sorrow for the suffering of God's people while affirming trust in God's saving power and faithfulness.
timeline: c. 586 BC - Babylonian destruction of Jerusalem and the temple

keyCharacters.name: Asaph
keyCharacters.description: The psalmist and leader of worship who composes this lament, expressing the communal grief and plea for God's intervention.

keyCharacters.name: The Heathen (Foreign Nations)
keyCharacters.description: The invading peoples who have destroyed Jerusalem, defiled the temple, and caused suffering to God's people.

keyCharacters.name: The Servants of God
keyCharacters.description: The faithful Israelites who have been killed and dishonored during the invasion, representing God's covenant people.

definitions.definition: Non-Israelite peoples who do not know or worship the true God, often depicted as enemies of God's people.
God's righteous zeal to protect His honor and covenant relationship against idolatry and unfaithfulness.
A cause of shame or disgrace; here it refers to the scorn and derision faced by God's people from surrounding nations.
A plea for God to cleanse and forgive the people's sins, removing guilt and restoring fellowship.

outline.heading: The Destruction and Defilement of Jerusalem
outline.description: The psalm opens with a vivid description of the foreign nations invading God's inheritance, defiling the temple, and leaving the dead unburied, highlighting the severity of the judgment and suffering.

outline.heading: The People's Shame and Plea for God's Anger to End
outline.description: The community expresses their disgrace before neighboring peoples and implores God to pour out His wrath on the enemies who have destroyed Jacob's dwelling.

outline.heading: A Request for Mercy and Forgiveness
outline.description: The psalmist asks God to remember His covenant mercy, forgive past sins, and deliver His people for the sake of His own name and glory.

outline.heading: A Call for God's Vindication and Justice
outline.description: The psalmist desires that God demonstrate His power by avenging the blood of His servants and repaying the reproach inflicted by their enemies.

outline.heading: A Commitment to Praise and Thanksgiving
outline.description: Despite the suffering, the people affirm their identity as God's flock and promise to give thanks and proclaim His praise forever.

application: Trust God in times of national or personal crisis, remembering His power to deliver and restore.
Confess and repent of sin quickly, seeking God's mercy to cleanse and renew your heart.
Pray earnestly for justice and vindication, leaving vengeance to God rather than taking it into your own hands.
Commit to praising God continually, even amid hardship, as a testimony of faith to future generations.

keyVerses.text: Help us, O God of our salvation, for the glory of thy name: and deliver us, and purge away our sins, for thy name's sake.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the heart of the psalmist's plea for God's mercy and deliverance, emphasizing God's glory as the motivation for salvation.

keyVerses.text: So we thy people and sheep of thy pasture will give thee thanks for ever: we will shew forth thy praise to all generations.
keyVerses.significance: This verse expresses the faithful response of thanksgiving and praise, affirming God's ongoing care and the community's commitment to worship.

keyVerses.text: How long, LORD? wilt thou be angry for ever? shall thy jealousy burn like fire?
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the psalmist's anguish and longing for God's anger to relent, highlighting the tension between divine justice and mercy.
